1124310.1007/11243.1572-901XTransition Metal ChemistryTransit Met Chem0340-42851572-901XSpringer International PublishingChams11243-016-0095-79510.1007/s11243-016-0095-7ArticleManganese(II) and cobalt(II) complexes based on pyridyl diimide: in situ ligand formation, crystal structures, and sorption propertiesLiGuo-Bi1aChengJia-Qi1PanRong-Kai1LiuSheng-Gui1dgrid.469319.00000000417903951School of Chemistry and Chemical EngineeringLingnan Normal University, Development Center for New Materials Engineering and Technology in Universities of Guangdong524048ZhanjiangPeople’s Republic of China15920510870@163.comlsgui@sohu.com41020161120164189179222192016207201620920164102016© Springer International Publishing Switzerland 20162016Abstract

Two complexes, namely {[Mn(L1)2(H2O)2]·0.5H2O}n (1) and {[Co(L2)(H2O)2]·4H2O}n (2), (L1,1,3-dioxo-2-pyridin-3-ylmethyl-6-[(pyridin-3-ylmethyl)-carbamoyl]-2,3-dihydro-1H-isoindole-5-carboxylic acid; L2,2,5-bis-[(pyridine-3-yl methyl)-carbamoyl]-terephthalic acid), were synthesized and characterized by elemental analysis, IR spectroscopy, thermogravimetric analysis, and X-ray single-crystal structure analysis. The ligands HL1 and HL2 were formed in situ by the hydrolysis of N,N′-bis(3-pyridylmethyl)-pyromellitic diimide (L). Apparently, Mn2+ acts as an asymmetric catalyst, such that a new asymmetric pyridinecarboxylate derivative ligand L1 is formed, while Co2+ acts as a symmetric catalyst, giving the pyridinedicarboxylate derivative ligand L2. Complex 1 has a 1D double-chain structure, in which the adjacent chains are arranged in parallel arrays through π···π interactions, resulting in a 2D supramolecular framework. Complex 2 has a grid (4,4)-sql net structure in an edge-to-edge arrangement through hydrogen bonds between adjacent layers, forming a 3D supramolecular framework containing 1D channels to accommodate water guest molecules. The thermal stabilities of both complexes and ethanol adsorption properties of complex 2 were investigated.

Graphical Abstract

1D double-chain Mn(II) complex (1) and 2D (4,4) net Co(II) complex (2) were synthesized. The Mn2+ ions have the asymmetric catalysis property, and a new asymmetric pyridinecarboxylates derivative ligand is formed; the Co2+ ions have symmetric catalysis property, giving the pyridinedicarboxylates derivative ligand. The complex 2 allows for stepwise sorption of ethanol.

Introduction

Coordination complexes with networked crystal structures are of current interest for their potential applications as fluorescent probes, gas adsorbers, magnetic materials, catalysts, and molecular sensors [1–5]. The rational design of such materials is dependent on the selection of suitable organic ligands, inorganic secondary building units (SBUs), and synthesis conditions, including pH value, solvent, temperature, and reagent concentration [6, 7]. The structures of the ligands also play a key role in the design and construction of such complexes [8]. In this context, the technique of in situ ligand synthesis has attracted attention, as a means to simplify preparation of organic ligands and construct new coordination complexes [9–11]. A few in situ ligand reactions have been documented; these include acylation, hydrolysis, hydroxylation, reduction, and nucleophilic addition [12–18].

The coordination chemistry of bis-pyridyl ligands has been intensely investigated [19–21]. Our group has been working on the supramolecular synthesis of various coordination polymer assemblies with semirigid ligands containing freely rotatable methylene linkers between a rigid spacer and pyridyl arms. A great diversity of both discrete molecular architectures and infinite coordination polymers has been constructed [22–26]. As part of our ongoing study of coordination complexes of diimide ligands, in this work we have synthesized two complexes based on the hydrolysis reactions of N,N′-bis(3-pyridylmethyl)pyromellitic diimide (Scheme S1). We found that the reactivity of the organic ligand can be greatly influenced by the choice of transition metal, such that the final structure of the resulting coordination complex can be varied. The thermal stabilities and guest adsorption properties of the new complexes have been investigated.

ExperimentalMaterials and methods

Chemicals were purchased from commercial sources and used without further purification. The pro-ligand L was prepared according to our previous report [23]. Elemental analyses (C, H, N) were obtained with a PerkinElmer 240C elemental analyzer. FTIR spectra were recorded from KBr pellets in the range of 4000–400 cm−1 on a Vector 22 spectrometer. Thermal analyses were performed on a TGA V5.1A Dupont 2100 instrument from room temperature to 800 °C, with a heating rate of 10 °C min−1 under nitrogen. The adsorption isotherm of EtOH (at 298 K) was measured using a BELmax 00027 adsorption instrument (BEL Japan). An exactly measured amount of the sample was introduced into the gas sorption instrument after pre-desolvation in a Schlenk tube at 110 °C under vacuum for 24 h. The adsorbate was placed into the sample tube, and then the change of pressure was monitored and the degree of adsorption determined by the decrease in pressure at equilibrium. The sorption properties were analyzed using Autosorb 1 for Windows 1.24 software.

Synthesis of {[Mn(L<sup>1</sup>)<sub>2</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>2</sub>]·0.5H<sub>2</sub>O}<sub><italic>n</italic></sub> (1)

A mixture of Mn(NO3)2·6H2O (36 mg, 0.125 mmol) and L (40.0 mg, 0.1 mmol) in MeOH (4.0 mL) plus CHCl3 (12.0 mL) was stirred and then sealed in a 20 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. The autoclave was heated to 110 °C and held at that temperature for 2 days, followed by cooling to room temperature. The resulting white precipitate was filtered off and washed with CHCl3, and then dried in air. Colorless block crystals of 1 were isolated by hand in 21 % yield based on L. Anal. Calcd for C44H35N8O12.5Mn: C, 56.78; H, 3.79; N, 12.04 %. Found: C, 56.37; H, 3.96; N, 11.86 %. IR data (KBr, cm−1): 3429vs, 2353w, 1772m, 1717s, 1664m, 1647w, 1598m, 1578m, 1535s, 1482w, 1432m, 1380s, 1359s, 1290w, 1200w, 1151w, 1098m, 1035w, 910w, 812w, 750w, 711m, 645w, 571w, 488w.

Synthesis of {[Co(L<sup>2</sup>)(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>2</sub>]·4H<sub>2</sub>O}<sub><italic>n</italic></sub> (2)

A mixture of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (36 mg, 0.125 mmol) and L (40.0 mg, 0.1 mmol) in MeOH (4.0 mL) plus CHCl3 (12.0 mL) was stirred and then sealed in a 20 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. The autoclave was heated to 110 °C and held at that temperature for 2 days, followed by cooling to room temperature. The resulting red precipitate was filtered off, washed with CHCl3, and dried in air. Red block crystals of 2 were isolated by hand in 25 % yield based on L. Anal. Calcd for C22H28N4O12Co: C, 44.08; H, 4.71; N, 9.35 %. Found: C, 43.87; H, 4.96; N, 9.16 %. IR data (KBr, cm−1): 3406vs, 2375w, 1632s, 1576s, 1484m, 1408s, 1349s, 1191w, 1139m, 1054m, 806w, 706m, 650w.

Crystal structure determinations

Crystallographic data for complexes 1 and 2 were collected at 153 and 293 K, respectively, on Bruker CCD diffractometers equipped with graphite-monochromated Cu-Kα radiation (λ = 1.54178 Å). The structures were solved by direct methods with SHELXS-97 [27] and refined by full-matrix least-squares techniques on F2 with SHELXL-97 [28]. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Most hydrogen atoms were introduced in calculated positions and refined with fixed geometry with respect to their carrier atoms; the water hydrogen atoms have not been included, due to their weak diffraction and disorder [29]. Details of the X-ray experiments and crystal data are summarized in Table 1. Selected bond lengths and angles are listed in Table 2.

Crystallographic data for the structures have been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre. (CCDC numbers of complexes 1 and 2 are 1480198 and 1480199, respectively; deposit@ccdc.cam.ac.uk or www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif).

Results and discussionIn situ ligand formation and structure analysis

Reactions of N,N′-bis(3-pyridylmethyl)pyromellitic diimide (L) with Mn(NO3)2·6H2O and Co(NO3)2·6H2O furnished the complexes 1 and 2, respectively. Surprisingly, the results of single-crystal structural analysis indicate that the Mn2+ centers in complex 1 are coordinated by four L1 ligands, while the Co2+ centers in complex 2 are coordinated by four L2 ligands, rather than the pro-ligand L. Hence, the pyridinecarboxylate derivative ligands were formed in situ, as illustrated in Scheme 1. Examples of solvothermal in situ reactions reported in the literature include a series of carboxylate-based coordination polymers produced by an in situ amide hydrolysis reaction [13–15]. However, to the best of our knowledge, the formation of a ligand via an asymmetric hydrolysis ring opening reaction has not been reported previously for solvothermal in situ reactions. We speculate that the Mn2+ ion acts as an asymmetric catalyst, such that a new asymmetric pyridinecarboxylate derivative ligand is formed [13, 23], whereas the Co2+ acts as a symmetric catalyst, resulting in hydrolysis of L to give a new pyridyl dicarboxylic acid ligand [14–16].

The crystallographic analysis revealed that complex 1 crystallizes in the triclinic system with space group P1¯\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$\bar{1}$$\end{document}. Its asymmetric unit contains one Mn2+ center, two L1 ligands, two water ligands, and one guest water molecule. The Mn2+ center adopts a distorted octahedral coordination sphere, defined by four O atoms from two water ligands and two independent L1 ligands in the equatorial plane, plus two N atoms from independent L1 ligands at the apexes (Fig. 1). The two Mn–O bond lengths are 2.170(3) and 2.223(3) Å, and the Mn–N bond length is 2.270(3) Å. The pyridinecarboxylate derivative ligand was formed in situ, as illustrated in Scheme 1. Among the solvothermal in situ reactions previously reported, a series of coordination complexes based on hydrolysis reactions have been reported [13–15]. In complex 1, one terminal Py group and the carbonyl O atom of the L1 ligand take on the “U-mode” conformation and link pairs of Mn2+ centers, such that a 1D zigzag chain is formed (Fig. 2). The L1 ligand acts as a molecular clip to bridge each pair of adjacent Mn2+ atoms on the same side, thus generating an M2L21 type metallacycle with an Mn–Mn separation of about 13.2 Å. The boat shape of the metallacycle is apparently determined by the conformation of the L1 ligands. One terminal Py group did not coordinate with the central Mn2+ atom, forming a 1D infinite double-chain structure propagating along the b axis direction. In complex 1, the rigid spacer pyromellitic imide planes are aligned in parallel, resulting in a rectangular metallacycle. The M2L21 rectangle lies about an inversion center, which is located in the middle of the metallacycle. As shown in Fig. 3, there are π···π stacking interactions (centroid distance, 3.79 Å) between the non-coordinating pyridyl rings and the coordinating pyridyl rings. The neighboring double chain is connected between the parallel pyridine rings and pyromellitic imide planes with distances of 3.930 and 3.813 Å via π···π stacking interactions, and the resulting chains are further stacked in a parallel style into a 2D supramolecular network. Thus, the normal parallel packing of the 1D chains is directed by these π···π interactions, generating 1D channels which are occupied by guest water molecules. There are also hydrogen bonds (N–H···O) between carboxylic O atoms and the amine groups; the neighboring guest water molecules (Table 3).

In complex 2, the coordination geometry of the Co(II) center can be described as a distorted octahedron, with four O atoms from two different L2 ligands and two water ligands in the equatorial plane, and pyridyl N donors from two independent L2 ligands at the apexes (Fig. 3). The two terminal Py groups take on the “U-mode” conformation to link together two Co2+ centers, while the dicarboxylate O atoms of the L2 ligands also bridge two Co2+ centers, such that a 2D grid is formed. In this grid network, the metal atoms serve as 4-connecting nodes and the L2 ligands as 4-connecting linkers to bridge Co2+ centers; the alternating connections between the metal nodes and the L2 linkers give rise to a 2D (4,4)-sql network (Fig. 4). The resulting layers are further stacked in parallel into a 3D framework with 1D quadrangalar channels. The individual 2D (4,4) layers in complex 2 are connected with adjacent layers by intermolecular N–H···O hydrogen bonds (H···O distance 2.89 Å) between carboxylic O atoms and the H atoms of the amine groups, as shown in Figure S3 (Table 3). There are also π···π stacking interactions (centroid distance, 3.82 Å) between the pyridyl rings, giving rise to a 3D supramolecular network.

Infrared spectra and thermal stabilities

The infrared spectra of free L and complexes 1 and 2 are shown in Figure S1. A band at 1707 cm−1 is characteristic of the C=O stretching vibration in free L. this band is absent from the spectra of both complexes; instead, new carboxylate bands are observed at 1433 and 1647 cm−1 for 1 and at 1408 and 1632 cm−1 for 2. The observation of the characteristic bands at 1598 and 1576 cm−1 for complexes 1 and 2, respectively, indicates deprotonation and coordination of the carboxylate groups. The N–H stretches are readily visible in the IR spectra with single bands at 3252 cm−1 for complex 1 and 3258 cm−1 for complex 2. Broad bands at 3429 and 3406 cm−1 for 1 and 2, respectively, are attributed to solvent water.

The thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) are shown in Fig. 5. For complex 1, a weight loss of 0.9 % below 130 °C is assigned to the loss of 0.5 guest water molecules (calcd. 1.0 %). Complex 1 is then stable up to 340 °C. Complex 2 has four main weight loss steps in the temperature range from 25 to 800 °C. The first loss, of 2.8 %, occurs between 25 and 130 °C, corresponding to the loss of one guest water molecule (calculated 3.0 %). The second occurs between 130 and 160 °C, amounting to about 15.7 %, corresponding to escape of three water guest molecules and two water ligands (calculated 15.1 %). The third weight loss between 180 and 250 °C amounts to about 31.4 %, corresponding to the decomposition of the organic ligands (calculated 35.6 %). Decomposition of complex 2 is complete at about 440 °C. The TG profile of complex 2 exhibits two stepwise losses of water, followed by a stable plateau between 160 and 200 °C. These results suggest that complex 2 may be a candidate for porous adsorbent materials, since it has a stable thermal plateau and permanent porosity. We therefore investigated the ethanol sorption properties of complex 2.

Ethanol sorption properties of complex 2

A sorption experiment with ethanol was carried out on complex 2 at 298 K (Fig. 6). The complex shows stepwise sorption. Ethanol (4.5 Å) can diffuse into the channels of complex 2. An increase in the amount of adsorbed vapor under low pressure (0–0.6) indicates an initial adsorption of 10.8 cm3 g−1 (STP), and then at 0.6–0.9, a rapid increase in adsorption of 58.6 cm3 g−1 (STP). At this point, the desorption curve did not trace the adsorption curve any longer, but showed a large hysteresis.

Conclusions

A 1D double-chain Mn(II) complex (1) and a 2D (4,4) net Co(II) complex (2) have been synthesized by in situ amide hydrolysis ring opening reactions of N,N′-bis(3-pyridylmethyl)-pyromellitic diimide. The reactions of this compound with Mn2+ and Co2+ give two hydrolysis products, which act as ligands. The complexes also have different crystal structures; complex 2 has a 2D (4,4)-sql network layered structure that allows for stepwise sorption of ethanol.

The resulting white precipitate was filtered off and washed with CHCl3, and then dried in air. Colorless block crystals of 1 were isolated by hand in 21 % yield based on L. Anal. Calcd for C44H35N8O12.5Mn: C, 56.78; H, 3.79; N, 12.04 %. Found: C, 56.37; H, 3.96; N, 11.86 %. IR data (KBr, cm-1): 3429vs, 2353w, 1772m, 1717s, 1664m, 1647w, 1598m, 1578m, 1535s, 1482w, 1432m, 1380s, 1359s, 1290w, 1200w, 1151w, 1098m, 1035w, 910w, 812w, 750w, 711m, 645w, 571w, 488w.Synthesis of {[Co(L2)(H2O)2]⋅4H2O}n (2)A mixture of Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O (36 mg, 0.125 mmol) and L (40.0 mg, 0.1 mmol) in MeOH (4.0 mL) plus CHCl3 (12.0 mL) was stirred and then sealed in a 20 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. The autoclave was heated to 110 °C and held at that temperature for 2 days, followed by cooling to room temperature. The resulting red precipitate was filtered off, washed with CHCl3, and dried in air. Red block crystals of 2 were isolated by hand in 25 % yield based on L. Anal. Calcd for C22H28N4O12Co: C, 44.08; H, 4.71; N, 9.35 %. Found: C, 43.87; H, 4.96; N, 9.16 %. IR data (KBr, cm-1): 3406vs, 2375w, 1632s, 1576s, 1484m, 1408s, 1349s, 1191w, 1139m, 1054m, 806w, 706m, 650w.Crystal structure determinationsCrystallographic data for complexes 1 and 2 were collected at 153 and 293 K, respectively, on Bruker CCD diffractometers equipped with graphite-monochromated Cu-Kα radiation (λ = 1.54178 Å). The structures were solved by direct methods with SHELXS-97 [27] and refined by full-matrix least-squares techniques on F2 with SHELXL-97 [28]. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Most hydrogen atoms were introduced in calculated positions and refined with fixed geometry with respect to their carrier atoms; the water hydrogen atoms have not been included, due to their weak diffraction and disorder [29]. Details of the X-ray experiments and crystal data are summarized in Table 1. Selected bond lengths and angles are listed in Table 2. Crystallographic data for the structures have been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre. (CCDC numbers of complexes 1 and 2 are 1480198 and 1480199, respectively; deposit@ccdc.cam.ac.uk or www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif).Results and discussionIn situ ligand formation and structure analysisReactions of N,N'-bis(3-pyridylmethyl)pyromellitic diimide (L) with Mn(NO3)2⋅6H2O and Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O furnished the complexes 1 and 2, respectively. Surprisingly, the results of single-crystal structural analysis indicate that the Mn2+ centers in complex 1 are coordinated by four L1 ligands, while the Co2+ centers in complex 2 are coordinated by four L2 ligands, rather than the pro-ligand L. Hence, the pyridinecarboxylate derivative ligands were formed in situ, as illustrated in Scheme 1. Examples of solvothermal in situ reactions reported in the literature include a series of carboxylate-based coordination polymers produced by an in situ amide hydrolysis reaction [13-15]. However, to the best of our knowledge, the formation of a ligand via an asymmetric hydrolysis ring opening reaction has not been reported previously for solvothermal in situ reactions. We speculate that the Mn2+ ion acts as an asymmetric catalyst, such that a new asymmetric pyridinecarboxylate derivative ligand is formed [13, 23], whereas the Co2+ acts as a symmetric catalyst, resulting in hydrolysis of L to give a new pyridyl dicarboxylic acid ligand [14-16].The crystallographic analysis revealed that complex 1 crystallizes in the triclinic system with space group P1¯\documentclass[12pt]{minimal}     \usepackage{amsmath}     \usepackage{wasysym}     \usepackage{amsfonts}     \usepackage{amssymb}     \usepackage{amsbsy}     \usepackage{mathrsfs}     \usepackage{upgreek}     \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt}     \begin{document}$$\bar{1}$$\end{document}. Its asymmetric unit contains one Mn2+ center, two L1 ligands, two water ligands, and one guest water molecule. The Mn2+ center adopts a distorted octahedral coordination sphere, defined by four O atoms from two water ligands and two independent L1 ligands in the equatorial plane, plus two N atoms from independent L1 ligands at the apexes (Fig. 1). The two Mn-O bond lengths are 2.170(3) and 2.223(3) Å, and the Mn-N bond length is 2.270(3) Å. The pyridinecarboxylate derivative ligand was formed in situ, as illustrated in Scheme 1. Among the solvothermal in situ reactions previously reported, a series of coordination complexes based on hydrolysis reactions have been reported [13-15]. In complex 1, one terminal Py group and the carbonyl O atom of the L1 ligand take on the "U-mode" conformation and link pairs of Mn2+ centers, such that a 1D zigzag chain is formed (Fig. 2). The L1 ligand acts as a molecular clip to bridge each pair of adjacent Mn2+ atoms on the same side, thus generating an M2L21 type metallacycle with an Mn-Mn separation of about 13.2 Å. The boat shape of the metallacycle is apparently determined by the conformation of the L1 ligands. One terminal Py group did not coordinate with the central Mn2+ atom, forming a 1D infinite double-chain structure propagating along the b axis direction. In complex 1, the rigid spacer pyromellitic imide planes are aligned in parallel, resulting in a rectangular metallacycle. The M2L21 rectangle lies about an inversion center, which is located in the middle of the metallacycle. As shown in Fig. 3, there are π⋅⋅⋅π stacking interactions (centroid distance, 3.79 Å) between the non-coordinating pyridyl rings and the coordinating pyridyl rings. The neighboring double chain is connected between the parallel pyridine rings and pyromellitic imide planes with distances of 3.930 and 3.813 Å via π⋅⋅⋅π stacking interactions, and the resulting chains are further stacked in a parallel style into a 2D supramolecular network. Thus, the normal parallel packing of the 1D chains is directed by these π⋅⋅⋅π interactions, generating 1D channels which are occupied by guest water molecules. There are also hydrogen bonds (N-H⋅⋅⋅O) between carboxylic O atoms and the amine groups; the neighboring guest water molecules (Table 3).In complex 2, the coordination geometry of the Co(II) center can be described as a distorted octahedron, with four O atoms from two different L2 ligands and two water ligands in the equatorial plane, and pyridyl N donors from two independent L2 ligands at the apexes (Fig. 3). The two terminal Py groups take on the "U-mode" conformation to link together two Co2+ centers, while the dicarboxylate O atoms of the L2 ligands also bridge two Co2+ centers, such that a 2D grid is formed. In this grid network, the metal atoms serve as 4-connecting nodes and the L2 ligands as 4-connecting linkers to bridge Co2+ centers; the alternating connections between the metal nodes and the L2 linkers give rise to a 2D (4,4)-sql network (Fig. 4). The resulting layers are further stacked in parallel into a 3D framework with 1D quadrangalar channels. The individual 2D (4,4) layers in complex 2 are connected with adjacent layers by intermolecular N-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonds (H⋅⋅⋅O distance 2.89 Å) between carboxylic O atoms and the H atoms of the amine groups, as shown in Figure S3 (Table 3). There are also π⋅⋅⋅π stacking interactions (centroid distance, 3.82 Å) between the pyridyl rings, giving rise to a 3D supramolecular network.Infrared spectra and thermal stabilitiesThe infrared spectra of free L and complexes 1 and 2 are shown in Figure S1. A band at 1707 cm-1 is characteristic of the C=O stretching vibration in free L. this band is absent from the spectra of both complexes; instead, new carboxylate bands are observed at 1433 and 1647 cm-1 for 1 and at 1408 and 1632 cm-1 for 2. The observation of the characteristic bands at 1598 and 1576 cm-1 for complexes 1 and 2, respectively, indicates deprotonation and coordination of the carboxylate groups. The N-H stretches are readily visible in the IR spectra with single bands at 3252 cm-1 for complex 1 and 3258 cm-1 for complex 2. Broad bands at 3429 and 3406 cm-1 for 1 and 2, respectively, are attributed to solvent water.The thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) are shown in Fig. 5. For complex 1, a weight loss of 0.9 % below 130 °C is assigned to the loss of 0.5 guest water molecules (calcd. 1.0 %). Complex 1 is then stable up to 340 °C. Complex 2 has four main weight loss steps in the temperature range from 25 to 800 °C. The first loss, of 2.8 %, occurs between 25 and 130 °C, corresponding to the loss of one guest water molecule (calculated 3.0 %). The second occurs between 130 and 160 °C, amounting to about 15.7 %, corresponding to escape of three water guest molecules and two water ligands (calculated 15.1 %). The third weight loss between 180 and 250 °C amounts to about 31.4 %, corresponding to the decomposition of the organic ligands (calculated 35.6 %). Decomposition of complex 2 is complete at about 440 °C. The TG profile of complex 2 exhibits two stepwise losses of water, followed by a stable plateau between 160 and 200 °C. These results suggest that complex 2 may be a candidate for porous adsorbent materials, since it has a stable thermal plateau and permanent porosity. We therefore investigated the ethanol sorption properties of complex 2.Ethanol sorption properties of complex 2A sorption experiment with ethanol was carried out on complex 2 at 298 K (Fig. 6). The complex shows stepwise sorption. Ethanol (4.5 Å) can diffuse into the channels of complex 2. An increase in the amount of adsorbed vapor under low pressure (0-0.6) indicates an initial adsorption of 10.8 cm3 g-1 (STP), and then at 0.6-0.9, a rapid increase in adsorption of 58.6 cm3 g-1 (STP). At this point, the desorption curve did not trace the adsorption curve any longer, but showed a large hysteresis.ConclusionsA 1D double-chain Mn(II) complex (1) and a 2D (4,4) net Co(II) complex (2) have been synthesized by in situ amide hydrolysis ring opening reactions of N,N'-bis(3-pyridylmethyl)-pyromellitic diimide. The reactions of this compound with Mn2+ and Co2+ give two hydrolysis products, which act as ligands. The complexes also have different crystal structures; complex 2 has a 2D (4,4)-sql network layered structure that allows for stepwise sorption of ethanol.AcknowledgmentsThis work was financially elements.content: Two complexes, namely {[Mn(L1)2(H2O)2]·0.5H2O}n (1) and {[Co(L2)(H2O)2]·4H2O}n (2), (L1,1,3-dioxo-2-pyridin-3-ylmethyl-6-[(pyridin-3-ylmethyl)-carbamoyl]-2,3-dihydro-1H-isoindole-5-carboxylic acid; L2,2,5-bis-[(pyridine-3-yl methyl)-carbamoyl]-terephthalic acid), were synthesized and characterized by elemental analysis, IR spectroscopy, thermogravimetric analysis, and X-ray single-crystal structure analysis. The ligands HL1 and HL2 were formed in situ by the hydrolysis of N,N′-bis(3-pyridylmethyl)-pyromellitic diimide (L). Apparently, Mn2+ acts as an asymmetric catalyst, such that a new asymmetric pyridinecarboxylate derivative ligand L1 is formed, while Co2+ acts as a symmetric catalyst, giving the pyridinedicarboxylate derivative ligand L2. Complex 1 has a 1D double-chain structure, in which the adjacent chains are arranged in parallel arrays through π···π interactions, resulting in a 2D supramolecular framework. Complex 2 has a grid (4,4)-sql net structure in an edge-to-edge arrangement through hydrogen bonds between adjacent layers, forming a 3D supramolecular framework containing 1D channels to accommodate water guest molecules. The thermal stabilities of both complexes and ethanol adsorption properties of complex 2 were investigated.

Abstract

Two complexes, namely {[Mn(L1)2(H2O)2]⋅0.5H2O}n (1) and {[Co(L2)(H2O)2]⋅4H2O}n (2), (L1,1,3-dioxo-2-pyridin-3-ylmethyl-6-[(pyridin-3-ylmethyl)-carbamoyl]-2,3-dihydro-1H-isoindole-5-carboxylic acid; L2,2,5-bis-[(pyridine-3-yl methyl)-carbamoyl]-terephthalic acid), were synthesized and characterized by elemental analysis, IR spectroscopy, thermogravimetric analysis, and X-ray single-crystal structure analysis. The ligands HL1 and HL2 were formed in situ by the hydrolysis of N,N'-bis(3-pyridylmethyl)-pyromellitic diimide (L). Apparently, Mn2+ acts as an asymmetric catalyst, such that a new asymmetric pyridinecarboxylate derivative ligand L1 is formed, while Co2+ acts as a symmetric catalyst, giving the pyridinedicarboxylate derivative ligand L2. Complex 1 has a 1D double-chain structure, in which the adjacent chains are arranged in parallel arrays through π⋅⋅⋅π interactions, resulting in a 2D supramolecular framework. Complex 2 has a grid (4,4)-sql net structure in an edge-to-edge arrangement through hydrogen bonds between adjacent layers, forming a 3D supramolecular framework containing 1D channels to accommodate water guest molecules. The thermal stabilities of both complexes and ethanol adsorption properties of complex 2 were investigated.

elements.content: 1D double-chain Mn(II) complex (1) and 2D (4,4) net Co(II) complex (2) were synthesized. The Mn2+ ions have the asymmetric catalysis property, and a new asymmetric pyridinecarboxylates derivative ligand is formed; the Co2+ ions have symmetric catalysis property, giving the pyridinedicarboxylates derivative ligand. The complex 2 allows for stepwise sorption of ethanol.

Graphical Abstract

1D double-chain Mn(II) complex (1) and 2D (4,4) net Co(II) complex (2) were synthesized. The Mn2+ ions have the asymmetric catalysis property, and a new asymmetric pyridinecarboxylates derivative ligand is formed; the Co2+ ions have symmetric catalysis property, giving the pyridinedicarboxylates derivative ligand. The complex 2 allows for stepwise sorption of ethanol.

elements.content: Coordination complexes with networked crystal structures are of current interest for their potential applications as fluorescent probes, gas adsorbers, magnetic materials, catalysts, and molecular sensors [1–5]. The rational design of such materials is dependent on the selection of suitable organic ligands, inorganic secondary building units (SBUs), and synthesis conditions, including pH value, solvent, temperature, and reagent concentration [6, 7]. The structures of the ligands also play a key role in the design and construction of such complexes [8]. In this context, the technique of in situ ligand synthesis has attracted attention, as a means to simplify preparation of organic ligands and construct new coordination complexes [9–11]. A few in situ ligand reactions have been documented; these include acylation, hydrolysis, hydroxylation, reduction, and nucleophilic addition [12–18].
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Coordination complexes with networked crystal structures are of current interest for their potential applications as fluorescent probes, gas adsorbers, magnetic materials, catalysts, and molecular sensors [1-5]. The rational design of such materials is dependent on the selection of suitable organic ligands, inorganic secondary building units (SBUs), and synthesis conditions, including pH value, solvent, temperature, and reagent concentration [6, 7]. The structures of the ligands also play a key role in the design and construction of such complexes [8]. In this context, the technique of in situ ligand synthesis has attracted attention, as a means to simplify preparation of organic ligands and construct new coordination complexes [9-11]. A few in situ ligand reactions have been documented; these include acylation, hydrolysis, hydroxylation, reduction, and nucleophilic addition [12-18].

elements.content: The coordination chemistry of bis-pyridyl ligands has been intensely investigated [19–21]. Our group has been working on the supramolecular synthesis of various coordination polymer assemblies with semirigid ligands containing freely rotatable methylene linkers between a rigid spacer and pyridyl arms. A great diversity of both discrete molecular architectures and infinite coordination polymers has been constructed [22–26]. As part of our ongoing study of coordination complexes of diimide ligands, in this work we have synthesized two complexes based on the hydrolysis reactions of N,N′-bis(3-pyridylmethyl)pyromellitic diimide (Scheme S1). We found that the reactivity of the organic ligand can be greatly influenced by the choice of transition metal, such that the final structure of the resulting coordination complex can be varied. The thermal stabilities and guest adsorption properties of the new complexes have been investigated.

elements.content: Chemicals were purchased from commercial sources and used without further purification. The pro-ligand L was prepared according to our previous report [23]. Elemental analyses (C, H, N) were obtained with a PerkinElmer 240C elemental analyzer. FTIR spectra were recorded from KBr pellets in the range of 4000–400 cm−1 on a Vector 22 spectrometer. Thermal analyses were performed on a TGA V5.1A Dupont 2100 instrument from room temperature to 800 °C, with a heating rate of 10 °C min−1 under nitrogen. The adsorption isotherm of EtOH (at 298 K) was measured using a BELmax 00027 adsorption instrument (BEL Japan). An exactly measured amount of the sample was introduced into the gas sorption instrument after pre-desolvation in a Schlenk tube at 110 °C under vacuum for 24 h. The adsorbate was placed into the sample tube, and then the change of pressure was monitored and the degree of adsorption determined by the decrease in pressure at equilibrium. The sorption properties were analyzed using Autosorb 1 for Windows 1.24 software.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental

Materials and methods

Chemicals were purchased from commercial sources and used without further purification. The pro-ligand L was prepared according to our previous report [23]. Elemental analyses (C, H, N) were obtained with a PerkinElmer 240C elemental analyzer. FTIR spectra were recorded from KBr pellets in the range of 4000-400 cm-1 on a Vector 22 spectrometer. Thermal analyses were performed on a TGA V5.1A Dupont 2100 instrument from room temperature to 800 °C, with a heating rate of 10 °C min-1 under nitrogen. The adsorption isotherm of EtOH (at 298 K) was measured using a BELmax 00027 adsorption instrument (BEL Japan). An exactly measured amount of the sample was introduced into the gas sorption instrument after pre-desolvation in a Schlenk tube at 110 °C under vacuum for 24 h. The adsorbate was placed into the sample tube, and then the change of pressure was monitored and the degree of adsorption determined by the decrease in pressure at equilibrium. The sorption properties were analyzed using Autosorb 1 for Windows 1.24 software.

Crystal structure determinations

Crystallographic data for complexes 1 and 2 were collected at 153 and 293 K, respectively, on Bruker CCD diffractometers equipped with graphite-monochromated Cu-Kα radiation (λ = 1.54178 Å). The structures were solved by direct methods with SHELXS-97 [27] and refined by full-matrix least-squares techniques on F2 with SHELXL-97 [28]. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Most hydrogen atoms were introduced in calculated positions and refined with fixed geometry with respect to their carrier atoms; the water hydrogen atoms have not been included, due to their weak diffraction and disorder [29]. Details of the X-ray experiments and crystal data are summarized in Table 1. Selected bond lengths and angles are listed in Table 2.

elements.content: Reactions of N,N′-bis(3-pyridylmethyl)pyromellitic diimide (L) with Mn(NO3)2·6H2O and Co(NO3)2·6H2O furnished the complexes 1 and 2, respectively. Surprisingly, the results of single-crystal structural analysis indicate that the Mn2+ centers in complex 1 are coordinated by four L1 ligands, while the Co2+ centers in complex 2 are coordinated by four L2 ligands, rather than the pro-ligand L. Hence, the pyridinecarboxylate derivative ligands were formed in situ, as illustrated in Scheme 1. Examples of solvothermal in situ reactions reported in the literature include a series of carboxylate-based coordination polymers produced by an in situ amide hydrolysis reaction [13–15]. However, to the best of our knowledge, the formation of a ligand via an asymmetric hydrolysis ring opening reaction has not been reported previously for solvothermal in situ reactions. We speculate that the Mn2+ ion acts as an asymmetric catalyst, such that a new asymmetric pyridinecarboxylate derivative ligand is formed [13, 23], whereas the Co2+ acts as a symmetric catalyst, resulting in hydrolysis of L to give a new pyridyl dicarboxylic acid ligand [14–16].
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

In situ ligand formation and structure analysis

Reactions of N,N'-bis(3-pyridylmethyl)pyromellitic diimide (L) with Mn(NO3)2⋅6H2O and Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O furnished the complexes 1 and 2, respectively. Surprisingly, the results of single-crystal structural analysis indicate that the Mn2+ centers in complex 1 are coordinated by four L1 ligands, while the Co2+ centers in complex 2 are coordinated by four L2 ligands, rather than the pro-ligand L. Hence, the pyridinecarboxylate derivative ligands were formed in situ, as illustrated in Scheme 1. Examples of solvothermal in situ reactions reported in the literature include a series of carboxylate-based coordination polymers produced by an in situ amide hydrolysis reaction [13-15]. However, to the best of our knowledge, the formation of a ligand via an asymmetric hydrolysis ring opening reaction has not been reported previously for solvothermal in situ reactions. We speculate that the Mn2+ ion acts as an asymmetric catalyst, such that a new asymmetric pyridinecarboxylate derivative ligand is formed [13, 23], whereas the Co2+ acts as a symmetric catalyst, resulting in hydrolysis of L to give a new pyridyl dicarboxylic acid ligand [14-16].

elements.content: The crystallographic analysis revealed that complex 1 crystallizes in the triclinic system with space group P1¯\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$\bar{1}$$\end{document}. Its asymmetric unit contains one Mn2+ center, two L1 ligands, two water ligands, and one guest water molecule. The Mn2+ center adopts a distorted octahedral coordination sphere, defined by four O atoms from two water ligands and two independent L1 ligands in the equatorial plane, plus two N atoms from independent L1 ligands at the apexes (Fig. 1). The two Mn–O bond lengths are 2.170(3) and 2.223(3) Å, and the Mn–N bond length is 2.270(3) Å. The pyridinecarboxylate derivative ligand was formed in situ, as illustrated in Scheme 1. Among the solvothermal in situ reactions previously reported, a series of coordination complexes based on hydrolysis reactions have been reported [13–15]. In complex 1, one terminal Py group and the carbonyl O atom of the L1 ligand take on the “U-mode” conformation and link pairs of Mn2+ centers, such that a 1D zigzag chain is formed (Fig. 2). The L1 ligand acts as a molecular clip to bridge each pair of adjacent Mn2+ atoms on the same side, thus generating an M2L21 type metallacycle with an Mn–Mn separation of about 13.2 Å. The boat shape of the metallacycle is apparently determined by the conformation of the L1 ligands. One terminal Py group did not coordinate with the central Mn2+ atom, forming a 1D infinite double-chain structure propagating along the b axis direction. In complex 1, the rigid spacer pyromellitic imide planes are aligned in parallel, resulting in a rectangular metallacycle. The M2L21 rectangle lies about an inversion center, which is located in the middle of the metallacycle. As shown in Fig. 3, there are π···π stacking interactions (centroid distance, 3.79 Å) between the non-coordinating pyridyl rings and the coordinating pyridyl rings. The neighboring double chain is connected between the parallel pyridine rings and pyromellitic imide planes with distances of 3.930 and 3.813 Å via π···π stacking interactions, and the resulting chains are further stacked in a parallel style into a 2D supramolecular network. Thus, the normal parallel packing of the 1D chains is directed by these π···π interactions, generating 1D channels which are occupied by guest water molecules. There are also hydrogen bonds (N–H···O) between carboxylic O atoms and the amine groups; the neighboring guest water molecules (Table 3).

In complex 2, the coordination geometry of the Co(II) center can be described as a distorted octahedron, with four O atoms from two different L2 ligands and two water ligands in the equatorial plane, and pyridyl N donors from two independent L2 ligands at the apexes (Fig. 3). The two terminal Py groups take on the “U-mode” conformation to link together two Co2+ centers, while the dicarboxylate O atoms of the L2 ligands also bridge two Co2+ centers, such that a 2D grid is formed. In this grid network, the metal atoms serve as 4-connecting nodes and the L2 ligands as 4-connecting linkers to bridge Co2+ centers; the alternating connections between the metal nodes and the L2 linkers give rise to a 2D (4,4)-sql network (Fig. 4). The resulting layers are further stacked in parallel into a 3D framework with 1D quadrangalar channels. The individual 2D (4,4) layers in complex 2 are connected with adjacent layers by intermolecular N–H···O hydrogen bonds (H···O distance 2.89 Å) between carboxylic O atoms and the H atoms of the amine groups, as shown in Figure S3 (Table 3). There are also π···π stacking interactions (centroid distance, 3.82 Å) between the pyridyl rings, giving rise to a 3D supramolecular network.

The two terminal Py groups take on the "U-mode" conformation to link together two Co2+ centers, while the dicarboxylate O atoms of the L2 ligands also bridge two Co2+ centers, such that a 2D grid is formed. In this grid network, the metal atoms serve as 4-connecting nodes and the L2 ligands as 4-connecting linkers to bridge Co2+ centers; the alternating connections between the metal nodes and the L2 linkers give rise to a 2D (4,4)-sql network (Fig. 4). The resulting layers are further stacked in parallel into a 3D framework with 1D quadrangalar channels. The individual 2D (4,4) layers in complex 2 are connected with adjacent layers by intermolecular N-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonds (H⋅⋅⋅O distance 2.89 Å) between carboxylic O atoms and the H atoms of the amine groups, as shown in Figure S3 (Table 3). There are also π⋅⋅⋅π stacking interactions (centroid distance, 3.82 Å) between the pyridyl rings, giving rise to a 3D supramolecular network.

elements.content: The infrared spectra of free L and complexes 1 and 2 are shown in Figure S1. A band at 1707 cm−1 is characteristic of the C=O stretching vibration in free L. this band is absent from the spectra of both complexes; instead, new carboxylate bands are observed at 1433 and 1647 cm−1 for 1 and at 1408 and 1632 cm−1 for 2. The observation of the characteristic bands at 1598 and 1576 cm−1 for complexes 1 and 2, respectively, indicates deprotonation and coordination of the carboxylate groups. The N–H stretches are readily visible in the IR spectra with single bands at 3252 cm−1 for complex 1 and 3258 cm−1 for complex 2. Broad bands at 3429 and 3406 cm−1 for 1 and 2, respectively, are attributed to solvent water.
elements.clean_text:
Infrared spectra and thermal stabilities

The infrared spectra of free L and complexes 1 and 2 are shown in Figure S1. A band at 1707 cm-1 is characteristic of the C=O stretching vibration in free L. this band is absent from the spectra of both complexes; instead, new carboxylate bands are observed at 1433 and 1647 cm-1 for 1 and at 1408 and 1632 cm-1 for 2. The observation of the characteristic bands at 1598 and 1576 cm-1 for complexes 1 and 2, respectively, indicates deprotonation and coordination of the carboxylate groups. The N-H stretches are readily visible in the IR spectra with single bands at 3252 cm-1 for complex 1 and 3258 cm-1 for complex 2. Broad bands at 3429 and 3406 cm-1 for 1 and 2, respectively, are attributed to solvent water.

elements.content: The thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) are shown in Fig. 5. For complex 1, a weight loss of 0.9 % below 130 °C is assigned to the loss of 0.5 guest water molecules (calcd. 1.0 %). Complex 1 is then stable up to 340 °C. Complex 2 has four main weight loss steps in the temperature range from 25 to 800 °C. The first loss, of 2.8 %, occurs between 25 and 130 °C, corresponding to the loss of one guest water molecule (calculated 3.0 %). The second occurs between 130 and 160 °C, amounting to about 15.7 %, corresponding to escape of three water guest molecules and two water ligands (calculated 15.1 %). The third weight loss between 180 and 250 °C amounts to about 31.4 %, corresponding to the decomposition of the organic ligands (calculated 35.6 %). Decomposition of complex 2 is complete at about 440 °C. The TG profile of complex 2 exhibits two stepwise losses of water, followed by a stable plateau between 160 and 200 °C. These results suggest that complex 2 may be a candidate for porous adsorbent materials, since it has a stable thermal plateau and permanent porosity. We therefore investigated the ethanol sorption properties of complex 2.

elements.content: A sorption experiment with ethanol was carried out on complex 2 at 298 K (Fig. 6). The complex shows stepwise sorption. Ethanol (4.5 Å) can diffuse into the channels of complex 2. An increase in the amount of adsorbed vapor under low pressure (0–0.6) indicates an initial adsorption of 10.8 cm3 g−1 (STP), and then at 0.6–0.9, a rapid increase in adsorption of 58.6 cm3 g−1 (STP). At this point, the desorption curve did not trace the adsorption curve any longer, but showed a large hysteresis.
elements.clean_text:
Ethanol sorption properties of complex 2

A sorption experiment with ethanol was carried out on complex 2 at 298 K (Fig. 6). The complex shows stepwise sorption. Ethanol (4.5 Å) can diffuse into the channels of complex 2. An increase in the amount of adsorbed vapor under low pressure (0-0.6) indicates an initial adsorption of 10.8 cm3 g-1 (STP), and then at 0.6-0.9, a rapid increase in adsorption of 58.6 cm3 g-1 (STP). At this point, the desorption curve did not trace the adsorption curve any longer, but showed a large hysteresis.

elements.content: A 1D double-chain Mn(II) complex (1) and a 2D (4,4) net Co(II) complex (2) have been synthesized by in situ amide hydrolysis ring opening reactions of N,N′-bis(3-pyridylmethyl)-pyromellitic diimide. The reactions of this compound with Mn2+ and Co2+ give two hydrolysis products, which act as ligands. The complexes also have different crystal structures; complex 2 has a 2D (4,4)-sql network layered structure that allows for stepwise sorption of ethanol.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

A 1D double-chain Mn(II) complex (1) and a 2D (4,4) net Co(II) complex (2) have been synthesized by in situ amide hydrolysis ring opening reactions of N,N'-bis(3-pyridylmethyl)-pyromellitic diimide. The reactions of this compound with Mn2+ and Co2+ give two hydrolysis products, which act as ligands. The complexes also have different crystal structures; complex 2 has a 2D (4,4)-sql network layered structure that allows for stepwise sorption of ethanol.

A mixture of Mn(NO3)2·6H2O (36 mg, 0.125 mmol) and L (40.0 mg, 0.1 mmol) in MeOH (4.0 mL) plus CHCl3 (12.0 mL) was stirred and then sealed in a 20 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. The autoclave was heated to 110 °C and held at that temperature for 2 days, followed by cooling to room temperature. The resulting white precipitate was filtered off and washed with CHCl3, and then dried in air. Colorless block crystals of 1 were isolated by hand in 21 % yield based on L. Anal. The thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) are shown in Fig. 5. For complex 1, a weight loss of 0.9 % below 130 °C is assigned to the loss of 0.5 guest water molecules (calcd. 1.0 %). Complex 1 is then stable up to 340 °C. Complex 2 has four main weight loss steps in the temperature range from 25 to 800 °C. The first loss, of 2.8 %, occurs between 25 and 130 °C, corresponding to the loss of one guest water molecule (calculated 3.0 %). The second occurs between 130 and 160 °C, amounting to about 15.7 %, corresponding to escape of three water guest molecules and two water ligands (calculated 15.1 %). The third weight loss between 180 and 250 °C amounts to about 31.4 %, corresponding to the decomposition of the organic ligands (calculated 35.6 %). Decomposition of complex 2 is complete at about 440 °C. The TG profile of complex 2 exhibits two stepwise losses of water, followed by a stable plateau between 160 and 200 °C. These results suggest that complex 2 may be a candidate for porous adsorbent materials, since it has a stable thermal plateau and permanent porosity. We therefore investigated the ethanol sorption properties of complex 2.

Ethanol sorption properties of complex 2

A sorption experiment with ethanol was carried out on complex 2 at 298 K (Fig. 6). The complex shows stepwise sorption. Ethanol (4.5 Å) can diffuse into the channels of complex 2. An increase in the amount of adsorbed vapor under low pressure (0–0.6) indicates an initial adsorption of 10.8 cm3 g−1 (STP), and then at 0.6–0.9, a rapid increase in adsorption of 58.6 cm3 g−1 (STP). At this point, the desorption curve did not trace the adsorption curve any longer, but showed a large hysteresis.

Complex 1 is then stable up to 340 °C. Complex 2 has four main weight loss steps in the temperature range from 25 to 800 °C. The first loss, of 2.8 %, occurs between 25 and 130 °C, corresponding to the loss of one guest water molecule (calculated 3.0 %). The second occurs between 130 and 160 °C, amounting to about 15.7 %, corresponding to escape of three water guest molecules and two water ligands (calculated 15.1 %). The third weight loss between 180 and 250 °C amounts to about 31.4 %, corresponding to the decomposition of the organic ligands (calculated 35.6 %). Decomposition of complex 2 is complete at about 440 °C. The TG profile of complex 2 exhibits two stepwise losses of water, followed by a stable plateau between 160 and 200 °C. These results suggest that complex 2 may be a candidate for porous adsorbent materials, since it has a stable thermal plateau and permanent porosity. We therefore investigated the ethanol sorption properties of complex 2.

Ethanol sorption properties of complex 2

A sorption experiment with ethanol was carried out on complex 2 at 298 K (Fig. 6). The complex shows stepwise sorption. Ethanol (4.5 Å) can diffuse into the channels of complex 2. An increase in the amount of adsorbed vapor under low pressure (0-0.6) indicates an initial adsorption of 10.8 cm3 g-1 (STP), and then at 0.6-0.9, a rapid increase in adsorption of 58.6 cm3 g-1 (STP). At this point, the desorption curve did not trace the adsorption curve any longer, but showed a large hysteresis.
